citation.article-title: A new species of melanin-producing bacteria of the genus Alteromonas.

p.s: Description of Alteromonas distincta sp. nov.
Alteromonas distincta (Dis. tin. cta. The species epithet is derived from the Latin masculine adjective distincta - distinct)
Cells are of a rod-like form with rounded ends; the average diameter is 0.91 μm, and the average length is 2.53 μm.

Cells are motile by means of one - two polar flagella located at the same pole or three - four flagella attached laterally and at one of the poles; some cells possess five - seven lateral and polar flagella.
Cells are gram-negative and strictly aerobic.
Spores and capsules are not formed.
On complex solid media containing seawater, the colonies are convex, smooth, glistening, translucent, black-brown pigmented, and 3 - 5 mm in diameter.
The pigment diffuses into the medium and forms a black-brown halo around the colonies in 10 - 12 h of growth.
The pigment is of a melanoid nature and is more actively produced at 4 - 15°C.
The presence of seawater or 1 - 6% NaCl is required for growth; no growth occurs without sodium ions.
Growth is possible within a pH range of 6.0 - 9.0 (with an optimum at 7.5 - 8.5) and a temperature range of 4 - 35°C (with an optimum at 20 - 25°C); no growth occurs at 40°C.
Cells are chemoorganoheterotrophic.
As the sole carbon and energy source, citrate, acetate, tyrosine, and arginine can be used.
Yeast extract, casein hydrolysate, gelatin, and tween-80 are utilized.
Sugars and alcohols are not used.
Catalase and oxidase tests are positive.
Starch, alginate, N-acetylglucosamine, and chitin are not hydrolyzed.
The DNA GC content is 43.8 mol %.
The type strain is KMM 638, which was isolated from a sponge collected at a depth of 350 m near the Komandorskie Islands.
The description of the strain is the same as for the species.
The strain has been deposited with the Collection of Marine Microorganisms of the Pacific Institute of Bioorganic Chemistry, Far Eastern Division of the Russian Academy of Sciences, Vladivostok.
